0.21.text:
Greetings. I am Herbert Erpaderp and today
I'm going to show you how I painted these

8.26.text:
These are plastic models from Warlord games
that I got in their British Carrier Section.

12.63.text:
This came with fifteen infantry figures too,
but I won't be painting those in this video

16.76.text:
because I painted them almost exactly the
same way as I painted my Commandos, which

20.88.text: I have already made a video about.

23.03.text:
You can click the video on the upper left
to go and see that or find the link in the

27.85.text:
I feel a need to state that I'm not modelling
a specific vehicle and I'm probably way off

32.21.text:
on historical colours... And I don't really
care.

35.55.text:
If you're looking for super historical accuracy
you might be in the wrong place...

39.47.text:
I've looked at a couple of guides and pictures
for ideas, but for the most part I'm just

44.01.text:
going with what I think looks good and is
convincing to me.

47.15.text:
Because it's me that these models need to
satisfy.

51.61.text:
The first thing to do, as always, is to prime
the model. Which has been attached to a popsicle

56.14.text:
stick with blu tack so the model can be painted
without being handled.

60.10.text: For this I used vallejo black surface primer.

63.08.text:
Next I base coated the entire model with vallejo
model colour bronze green. This is a good

67.39.text:
example of just trying colours to see if I
like them. This was a bit darker and more

71.96.text:
grey than I was expecting and I didn't really
like it.

74.88.text:
I still applied a highlight of bronze green
mixed with buff, about a 50:50 mix and I left

80.37.text:
it for a couple of days just to see if maybe
I would change my mind.

84.17.text:
I didn't change my mind, so I resprayed the
models with vallejo model colour Russian Uniform.

89.63.text:
I tried to spray this fairly heavily, but
not so heavy as to completely obscure the

93.89.text:
bronze green underneath. I figured it would
add a really subtle variation to the colour

99.89.text:
I don't think this was especially effective
and I would certainly not suggest others do

103.72.text:
it unless you also for whatever reason tried
bronze green as a base coat and like me decided

110.23.text:
As you can see the colours are really quite
different.

113.15.text:
I then made a mix of roughly 3 parts Russian
Uniform and 1 part Buff. I sprayed this onto

118.55.text:
the model from above to try and give a subtle
highlighting on upper surfaces.

122.70.text:
It's kind of hard to see, especially on camera,
but if I place them side by side you can see

127.94.text:
the effect on the model further away from
the camera.

130.62.text:
I then decided to add further highlighting.
I made another mix of russian green and buff,

135.67.text: this time it was a 50:50 mix.

137.91.text:
And I dry brushed this highlight on, mostly
trying to focus on the upper edges and sharp

142.22.text:
corners of the model, though I definitely
am hitting most of the surfaces of the carrier.

146.90.text:
I feel this gives the model a nice kind of
dusty, faded after being in the sun for ages

152.78.text:
Here's another side by side comparison to
show the difference this dry brushing has

157.71.text:
Next I decided these carriers need to be a
little darker, so I applied a wash of secret

161.97.text:
weapon sewer water, which just sounds lovely
doesn't it.

165.44.text:
I thinned this roughly five parts thinner
to one part sewer water.

169.08.text:
I apply this fairly lightly all over the model
using a fairly wide, cheap, beaten up brush.

173.98.text:
This wash is fluid enough that it shouldn't
get brush strokes from using a crappy brush.

178.85.text:
As you can see this gives the model a more
yellowy green tint, though the wash is still

184.57.text:
I feel it adds another level of dirtiness
to the model.

187.62.text:
I then applied another drybrushing of roughly
50:50 russian uniform and buff.

192.43.text:
I tried to go a bit lighter with this, focusing
mostly on the edges, but I did still kind

197.18.text:
of go a bit heavy. That's okay. I think it
works and makes even more variation in the

203.34.text:
In hindsight I probably should have applied
the sewer water wash before doing any of the

208.26.text:
drybrushing, but I feel like this has worked
pretty well anyway.

211.78.text:
Next I apply an edge highlight using model
colour stone grey.

215.26.text:
As the name implies I apply this highlight
along all the sharp edges and raised bits

220.48.text:
The reason I chose to use stone grey is because
it's fairly close to the mix of uniform greeen

224.91.text:
and buff, but a little lighter. So it's different,
but not so different that it looks out of

231.07.text:
I do this with a fine brush, in this case
the insane detail brush from the army painter.

235.68.text:
I take my time and apply this carefully to
avoid making mistakes.

239.48.text:
I didn't bother applying this around the top
edges of the carrier because that area is

243.34.text:
going to receive a lot more chipping anyway,
so it seemed a little bit redundant to do

248.65.text:
You can see the result does stand out a fair
bit. That's what I was going for.

252.85.text:
It will blend in a bit more later after chipping
and various washes and weathering are applied.

258.18.text:
Now the basic colour of the carriers is applied
it's time to put some decals on.

262.46.text:
In preparation for this I brushed on a coat
of minitaire gloss coat to the areas where

270.09.text:
I used the star, bridging weight number, arm
of service marking, and vehicle number from

275.25.text:
the decal set that came with the british carrier
section box set.

279.05.text:
For the divisional badge I used decals from
a stand alone warlord british guards armoured

283.27.text: division set I've had for a while.

285.58.text:
As I normally do I used humbrol Decalfix to
apply these decals and they went on very easily.

291.26.text:
I really enjoy it when decals just work as
they should.

294.87.text:
I did almost have trouble with one of the
stars on the side. The very tip folded over

299.21.text:
on itself a tiny bit, but I was able to fix
it.

302.77.text:
Also the small numbers on the side were a
bit tricky to move around. There are a few

307.18.text:
different number sets on these decal sheets
so you can retry if you do mess them up. Fortunately

312.58.text: I didn't have to do that.

314.33.text:
As with most decal applications you just have
to be careful and take your time.

318.69.text:
Use a brush to manipulate the decals. If they
become hard to move use the tip of a sharp

323.65.text: knife VERY carefully to drag them around.

326.71.text:
The markings I have chosen aren't based on
any specific carriers, thou gh I did reference

331.04.text:
a couple of pictures to figure out their placement
and Fog of War's video Understanding British

335.91.text: vehicle markings & decals was also quite helpful.

339.43.text:
If you want to see that video I'll put a link
in the description.

342.64.text:
In the end though, even if my decals aren't
historically accurate, they look convincing

346.78.text: enough to me, which is what matters.

349.05.text:
I leave the decals to set over night and then
seal them in with some minitaire satin varnish

354.43.text:
and then it's time to dirty them up a little
bit.

356.80.text:
Because they're way too fresh and new looking
at the moment.

360.18.text:
First in an attempt to kill some of the brightness
of the white I apply some secret weapon concrete

365.84.text:
This was mixed one part concrete wash to two
parts vallejo airbrush thinner, though you

371.85.text:
I had just decided to see if using the thinner
instead of water with my washes would make

377.14.text:
I use a fine brush to apply this very lightly
to the decal. I try to avoid getting it on

382.12.text: the green areas if I can.

383.85.text:
I'm not entirely sure how effective this layer
is, but It does seem to add a tiny bit of

388.34.text:
imperfection and variation to the colour of
the markings, which is what I want.

392.81.text:
I then repeat the same process using army
painter strong tone thinned 1 part strong

397.00.text:
tone to two parts thinner. Again, water could
be used instead.

401.26.text:
With this I'm not all that worried about getting
the wash on the green areas.

404.90.text:
I try not to go too heavily with this. There
will be much more weathering later so it's

409.69.text:
not like this is the last chance to alter
the way the decals look. I do want to blend

414.20.text:
them into the rest of the vehicle as much
as I can though.

417.53.text:
When applying this I try to brush it on in
downward strokes, that way if there are any

421.69.text: visible streaks it might look like rain marks.

425.07.text:
To blend the decals in further I add some
chipping. I use russian uniform and again

429.73.text:
with the fine brush gently add some little
chips and scratches to the decals.

434.06.text:
The idea here to represent the paint of the
markings being scratched off, but not so hard

438.85.text:
that the green paint underneath would also
be scratched off.

442.23.text:
the decals have ended up looking fairly beat
up. Maybe a little bit too much, but I do

448.70.text:
Continuing with the chipping I mix vallejo
model colour black grey with model colour

454.29.text:
I lost track of the actual ratio for this
mix, but it's something like two parts black

458.93.text: grey to one part mahogany brown.

461.59.text:
I play with it until I'm happy that it looks
like a kind of tarnished dark steelish colour.

466.22.text:
I apply it with a piece of foam from some
model packaging and I use that to just dab

470.19.text: it on in an up and down motion only.

472.53.text:
If you drag this along the surface of the
model it will just look like a messy streak

476.21.text:
of paint and not at all like chipping, so
up and down motions only is the way to do

481.96.text:
It was my intention to focus this mostly around
the top of the carrier where men would be

485.88.text:
jumping in and out of the vehicle. It makes
sense to me that the paint here would get

490.88.text:
I think I might have gone a little overboard
with it though. I got excited. And I figure

495.74.text:
these are hard working little vehicles with
men climbing in and out all the time, so maybe

500.31.text: it's not such a bad thing.

502.59.text:
Side by side you can see this step makes a
significant difference.

506.12.text:
To finish off the scratches I take the same
mixture of black grey and mahogany and using

510.41.text:
a fine brush I applied some small scratches
and chips into areas I couldn't easily reach

516.03.text:
This is also how you would add long thin scratches
if that's what you wanted.

520.46.text:
Next it is time to base coat the rest of the
things.

522.96.text:
I do this after applying the chipping because
it's obviously hard to avoid getting the chipping

528.60.text:
I start with the tracks. I use model colour
black grey for these.

532.44.text:
I paint the entirety of the tracks, don't
forget the underside of the upper tracks.

537.09.text:
I also paint the tyres on the road wheels
with the same colour being careful to try

541.19.text:
not to paint the metal rim parts. This is
pretty easy, though a little bit time consuming.

546.18.text:
Don't forget the spare wheel if you included
them on your carriers and also the metal components

551.04.text: of the tools on the rear.

552.68.text:
I then drybrush the tracks with model colour
london grey. I mostly focus this on the edge

557.21.text: of the tracks and the raised part of the treads.

560.10.text:
I also use a smaller brush and drybrush the
same colour onto the edges of the road wheel

565.83.text:
Then, because despite my attempts to be neat,
I still got the greys onto the wheel rims

570.77.text:
I fixed those using model colour stone grey
and a fine brush.

574.53.text:
This is easy to get on the rims neatly because
they're raised. You can use the side of the

579.06.text:
brush and run it across the raised area to
avoid the surrounding areas.

583.28.text:
The result is a little stark, but washes and
weathering will take care of that.

587.80.text:
The intention of this wash is mostly just
to darken down the tracks a little bit.

591.96.text:
This is a roughly 50:50 mix of army painter
dark tone and thinner.

595.66.text:
I just apply this fairly heavily to all areas
of the tracks.

599.09.text:
I also add it to the wheels, focusing mostly
on the tyres, but it also makes the green

604.18.text:
parts look dirty and used, so don't worry
about getting it on those parts too.

608.95.text:
I apply it to the springs and because I'm
a numpty you can see at this point that I've

613.69.text:
forgotten to apply grey to the return rollers
there...

616.84.text:
Of course, don't forget to apply this to the
spare wheels and metal tool parts. Though

621.38.text:
I didn't video myself applying it to the tools
for some reason.

625.34.text:
Next I basecoated the tarps on the rear of
the carriers. Or at least I assume they're

630.85.text:
Whatever these rolled up things on the back
of the models are I painted them with model

636.10.text:
Not really sure what colour these should really
be, or what they are, but I thought they would

640.34.text:
look good in this colour. So that's what I
went with.

643.51.text:
I am, of course careful to try and avoid getting
this colour anywhere but the tarp. Fixing

648.25.text:
mistakes on the green surfaces at this point
would be a bit annoying.

652.66.text:
Because of how much I thinned this colour
I had to do a couple of coats of this to get

656.10.text:
as solid a coating as I wanted, but that's
not surprising.

660.10.text:
Then I apply a wash of strong tone, mixed
roughly 50:50 with thinner

664.43.text:
I apply this fairly heavily to the brown areas
of the roll thing trying to get the wash to

668.42.text:
build up quite a bit in the recesses around
the straps.

672.03.text:
Once that wash was dry I apply the US field
drab again. This time using a drybrush.

677.00.text:
I try not to go too heavily with this and
obviously still try to avoid getting the field

681.30.text: drab onto the body of the carrier.

683.32.text:
I make sure to hit the the edges of the roll,
both on the upper side and underside.

687.79.text: I think it looks a lot better already

690.60.text:
Next I apply another drubrushing. This time
with vallejo model colour Iraqui sand.

695.83.text:
This time I'm using a smaller drybrush and
trying to focus on the ridges and along the

701.14.text:
I applied this colour just to see if I might
like how it looks, Turns out I did. It's a

706.17.text:
little bit bright at the moment, but there
will be more washes down the road that will

711.47.text:
The next sensible step would be to paint the
straps holding the roll in place.

715.28.text:
I did this with AK interactive red brown leather,
just because I enjoy this colour quite a bit.

720.87.text:
Obviously I do this carefully so as to avoid
accidentally painting the roll with the leather

725.11.text:
colour. The trick with this kind of thing
is to just take your time

728.29.text:
Now the buckle needs some attention. I've
chosen to paint this in a metallic colour.

732.99.text: Specifically Vallejo game air bright bronze.

735.25.text:
I carefully paint the buckles with a fine
brush.

738.03.text:
I do try to be as neat as I possibly can with
this, metallic colours are a bit of a pain

742.62.text:
to fix mistakes with, though a dark wash later
will help cover some minor errors.

747.42.text:
Continuing on with the metallics I'm going
to paint the bren guns with Italeri flat gun

752.22.text:
I'm going to paint these a bit like I painted
the guns in my recent flames of war infantry

757.28.text:
Since the bren gun is almost entirely metal
this is pretty easy. Though I am careful to

763.45.text:
It is a little bit harder to paint the gun
in the front of the carrier, but not too difficult

768.85.text:
It will be hard to see so it doesn't have
to be perfect anyway.

772.78.text:
These are obviously quite shiny, but that's
okay.

776.04.text:
After this colour had dried I darken it down
with a wash of secret weapon heavy body black

780.22.text:
wash diluted roughly 50:50 with vallejo airbrush
thinner.

784.39.text:
Simply brush it fairly roughly onto all the
metal parts of the guns. You might need to

789.07.text: do a second coat of this.

791.13.text:
The idea here is to have the gun look black
at a distance, but with a slightly metallic

795.29.text:
look to it in certain lights and up close,
with a subtle metallic highlight on the raised

801.42.text:
I then applied undiluted strong tone to the
tarp straps. I focus most of this along the

806.19.text: edges of the straps and in the buckles.

808.87.text: It looks maybe a little too dark.

810.99.text:
To try and even that out I thin down some
strong tone one part strong tone to two parts

815.86.text:
thinner and apply it to the roll to try darken
that down so it looks a bit more consistent

821.42.text:
Make sure to get this into the gaps on the
ends of the rolls of course.

824.86.text:
Then I highlight the straps using the AK interactive
red leather again. This is so thin right out

829.79.text:
of the bottle that it works really well for
doing this kind of thing.

833.15.text:
The idea is to bring back some of the original
colour without obliterating the darker washed

838.96.text:
Next I paint the wooden stock of the bren
guns with vallejo model air mahogony.

843.16.text:
Apply this carefully so as not to get any
brown on areas that should remain green.

847.88.text: Don't forget to paint the handles too.

850.02.text:
And of course remember to paint both sides
of the gun... Nobody wants a half painted

855.25.text:
next I painted the tool handles on the rear
of the vehicle.

858.14.text: I used model colour beige brown for this.

860.57.text:
I'm not entirely sure if these are even meant
to be wooden handles... but... well... now

866.44.text: What are you going to do about it?

868.70.text:
Then to add a little variation to these handles
I apply some army painter strong tone straight

874.22.text: I apply it lightly with a fine brush.

876.98.text:
Next I decided I might try to fancy up the
stocks of the bren guns.

880.66.text:
I did this with model air mud brown. I used
a fine brush and streaked a couple of lines

885.49.text: here in an attempt to represent a wood grain...

888.42.text:
This was kind of hard to do in front of the
camera.

890.89.text:
Also I didn't bother applying it to the gun
in the front of the vehicle. It won't be visible

895.29.text: enough anyway to be worth the hassle.

897.34.text:
Then, because I want the wood grain effect
to be quite subtle I apply a wash of undiluted

901.82.text:
army painter dark tone to the wood parts.
Just to make it nice and dark.

906.11.text:
In all the pictures I see of this gun the
stocks always seem to look really dark.

910.41.text: I did two layers of this for optimal darkness.

913.69.text:
After this I applied a coat of satin varnish
to protect the paint I've done so far.

918.17.text:
For this I used minitaire. This is the first
model on which I've used any of their products,

922.76.text: and they seem to work quite well so far.

924.47.text:
I leave that to dry over night and then I
apply AK interactive enamel track wash.

929.67.text:
I brush this fairly heavily onto the tracks.
It will pool in the recesses and look like

936.29.text:
Apply it all over the track on both sides,
of course being careful to avoid getting it

940.56.text: onto the wheels, suspension and hull.

942.63.text:
Though it wouldn't be hard to remove from
those places anyway if you had to.

946.53.text:
I then take AK interactive dark brown enamel
wash and put it in all the gaps and crevices

952.55.text:
I also slop some onto areas that might look
a bit more dirty and grimy. It can be removed

957.67.text:
later if I don't like it, or if it's too messy,
so none of this needs to be especially neat.

962.82.text:
I put a lot of this in the engine grills to
give those some depth. And around things like

967.42.text:
the machine gun pole. Where it makes sense
for grime to accumulate.

971.01.text:
Capillary action works quite well with these
enamels in the gaps so make use of it where

976.62.text:
It's also a good idea to get this in the the
suspension gear. Those parts are bound to

980.36.text: be all greasy and grimy in short order.

982.58.text:
I didn't record it because I'm a dunce, but
I clean up the wash using a clean brush with

986.79.text:
clean white spirits on to gently rub away
the excess dark brown. This is easy and you'll

992.19.text: see me doing it in the following steps.

994.51.text:
You can see the difference applying this effect
has made to the lower model. It looks more

998.56.text:
interesting than the other one. At least to
me.

1001.37.text:
I left the enamels to dry over night and then
applied another layer of minitaire satin varnish.

1006.61.text:
I then apply AK interactive dark streaking
grime. This is also pretty easy to do. As

1012.23.text:
the name would seem to imply this is for making
streaks. So you just streak it on in a downwards

1018.87.text:
You could do thicker or thinner streaks than
I have. It's all personal taste.

1023.10.text:
Next I take my clean brush with thinner on
it and wipe away most of the colour. Again

1027.33.text:
in a downward motion to simulate the grime
running down the model with rain.

1031.34.text:
I removed most of the colour because the model
is already fairly dirty looking and it was

1036.00.text:
my hope that hese streaks would just add a
nice subtle extra touch.

1039.68.text:
I followed this with some AK interactive rain
marks for nato tanks.

1043.78.text:
I've never used this, but I figured I might
as well give it a try.

1047.35.text:
It goes on the same way as the dark streaking
grime, which I did leave a little heavier

1051.65.text:
than I wanted it to end up because I knew
I wasn't going to put a layer of varnish between

1057.09.text:
As with the dark streaking grime I rub the
rain marks away in a downward motion with

1061.03.text: a clean brush with clean thinner on it.

1063.26.text:
This will of course blend in the rain marks
and further blend and wipe away the dark streaking

1068.51.text: I ended up removing most of both colours.

1071.13.text:
You can see some of the rain marks has accumulated
in the gap at the top of the hull.

1075.34.text:
I just take my clean brush and get the bristles
into the gap to remove that. Easy enough.

1080.17.text:
I then apply some AK interactive enamel light
rust wash to the tracks.

1084.45.text:
I try to do this fairly lightly. And after
brushing it on I then go over it again with

1089.28.text: the brush dipped in a little bit of thinner.

1091.51.text:
These bren carriers are looking filthy and
well used, but they're not rusting hulks and

1096.21.text:
are probably looked after well enough, so
the only place I bother with this rust is

1100.81.text:
the tracks. Really it just makes them look
a bit more dirty than rusty I think.

1105.62.text:
Then I apply yet another coat of satin varnish.
When it's dry I lightly spray the model with

1110.31.text:
AK interactive summer kursk earth. I thinned
this roughly one part kursk earth to two part

1116.59.text:
I want this to represent dust, not mud, so
spraying this very, very thin and lightly

1122.06.text:
I focus this on the lower half and sides of
the carrier. I want the darker dust colour

1126.42.text:
on the lower half and some lighter dust on
top.

1129.38.text:
For the lighter dust I sprayed AK interactive
Africa dust effects, thinned at roughly the

1133.82.text: same ratio as the previous colour.

1136.14.text:
And obviously this time I focus on the upper
half of the model.

1139.38.text:
The good thing about using these enamels is
that you can remove it from any areas you

1142.97.text:
don't want it. I used a brush with clean thinner
on it to remove the dust from the bren guns

1150.11.text:
Now it's about time to add the crew. Or at
least give them their heads.

1154.25.text:
At this point they weren't completely painted,
but I thought it was worth adding their heads

1158.40.text:
now. It's pretty easy. I just clip off the
brass rod they had been attached to for painting

1163.02.text: as close to the head as I could.

1165.40.text:
Then super glue it into place. It's a good
idea to test fit these first and think about

1169.63.text:
where you want the head to be looking before
gluing.

1172.38.text:
I will leave the passengers out until after
the model has been matte varnished.

1176.85.text:
Again I didn't show the painting of these
figures because they've been painted almost

1180.28.text:
exactly the same way as the british commandos
I painted a while ago. If you want to see

1184.63.text:
that click the video in the upper left corner,
or the link in the description.

1188.90.text:
The only real difference these figures have
is different hats, which I base coated with

1195.57.text:
Of course, being a numpty I forgot to paint
the steering wheel. I used vallejo model air

1202.61.text:
This definitely would have been much easier
if I'd done it before gluing heads on.

1207.44.text:
Next I figured I would use this mig gun metal
pigment that I've had sitting around for however

1212.79.text:
I put it on my finger and rub it onto to the
raised part of the tracks. This of course

1217.16.text:
represents where the tracks have been worn
to a shine from driving around on hard surfaces.

1221.78.text:
This was kind of tricky to get onto the parts
just below the mud guards, but I got there

1226.98.text:
I also applied a little bit of this to the
edges of the passenger compartment because

1230.57.text:
I figure that would get a lot of wear too.
The shine there is very subtle. Also I forgot

1236.91.text:
Be careful when applying this. It's very easy
to accidentally get the pigment into places

1242.75.text:
You can also do this with a 2B pencil, which
is a bit less messy, but with that you run

1247.62.text: the risk of scratching the paint beneath.

1249.80.text:
As a little finishing touch for one carrier
I glued in this pile of piat ammo and back

1254.85.text: packs, as well as this PIAT launcher.

1257.65.text:
Probably against regulations to just dump
ammo and the launcher in there like that,

1261.64.text: but who cares. War is a crazy place, man.

1264.96.text:
The main idea behind that is just to have
a nice little something to add some variety

1269.98.text:
I give the bren carriers and their crews a
coat of matte varnish. At first I tried using

1275.05.text:
the minitaire flat coat, but it wasn't as
flat as I would have liked, so instead I applied

1279.96.text:
AK interactive ultra matte varnish, which
works really well.

1283.87.text:
Once that's done I sit the passengers in the
carriers. I haven't glued them in yet, but

1289.34.text:
So there we have it. That's how I painted
these 28mm scale Bren gun carriers. Or universal

1295.26.text: carriers if you prefer that name.

1297.52.text:
I'm pretty happy with them. At least the vehicles
themselves. The crew figures are okay, I mean,

1303.31.text:
If I didn't like them I'd strip them and start
again. I just feel I don't do as good a job

1307.79.text:
with figures as I do with vehicles. But that's
okay As long as I improve as I go that's fine.

1314.23.text:
I think I got just the right amount of dustiness
with these. They're obviously dusty, but it's

1319.72.text:
not overpowering. And I'm very glad that I
thought to paint the crew figures after applying

1325.42.text:
It makes sense that they probably wouldn't
be weathered the same as the vehicle. Especially

1329.41.text:
if they've only just got in and not been riding
around as the carrier gradually became dirty...

1336.05.text:
I think if I were to do this again I might
give them a bit less chipping. I do find it

1341.00.text:
hard not to go a little overboard with the
chipping, and maybe a little less grime would

1346.89.text:
I think the pigment on the tracks has worked
fairly well after the matte varnish.

1350.66.text:
You can see it's still there, but it's not
overpowering or anything like that. I like

1356.23.text:
In the end I'm quite happy to add these to
the rest of my painted bolt action british

1361.37.text:
If you want to see this little vehicle in
action I plan to play at least one solo game

1365.13.text:
of bolt action which I will be making a video
about and these are included in my british

1371.74.text:
You'll also see the infantry that came in
this British carrier section box set.

1375.93.text:
So if you're interested in that then stick
around. I'll get it done some time...

1380.67.text:
For those who are interested I'll include
a list of the paints I used to paint these

1386.22.text:
As always I highly recommend making your own
choices for colours that are asthetically

1390.09.text:
pleasing to you, but it's nice to have suggestions
as a starting point.

1395.03.text:
Hopefully this video has been helpful or interesting
for you. If you have any questions comments

1399.85.text:
or suggestions feel free to leave them in
the comment section below.

1403.18.text:
If there's anything you saw in this video
that you'd like a more in depth explanation

1406.93.text:
or demonstration of let me know and I might
do a herbert erpaderp's quick tips video about

1412.57.text:
Or Maybe I've already done one... You could
be watching this in the future... oooooh.

1421.61.text:
If you liked this video you can let me know
by clicking the thumbs up button.

1425.24.text:
If you think it should be flushed down the
shitter, then obviously click the thumbs down

1429.99.text:
If you feel so inclined I'd also appreciate
it if you did the other youtubey things like

1436.00.text:
And if you REALLY like the videos I make please
consider becoming a patron and helping to

1441.25.text:
Head over to patreon dot com slash herbert
erpaderp and for as little as a dollar a month

1445.47.text:
you can see my videos early, watch some patron
only bonus content and be super cool.

1452.88.text:
Click the patreon logo on screen now or the
link in the video description.

1456.81.text:
If patreon isn't your thing, that's okay.
I hope you enjoy my videos anyway.

1461.29.text:
I shall return soon, so until then happy modelling
and thanks for watching. Farewell.
